Text.#text: MOM, 50s, Ruth’s mother, tries too hard
DAD, 50s, Ruth’s father, doesn’t try hard enough
NATE, Ruth’s friend from high school, seems cool
KEVIN, wishes he were a black guy

A banner across the far wall that reads, "Welcome Home Ruthie!" A full bed with pink sheets and a pillow depicting Rapunzel. Above the bed on the wall, a poster of Sigourney Weaver and the Zenomorph from Alien. In front of the bed, a large wooden chest, closed, and a door leading out of the room. On the other side of the room, a desk near a bathroom door. A window leading out onto the roof. Grey sky outside. A lone balloon tied to the foot of the bed.

RUTH, her MOM, and her DAD sit on the bed, frozen in a tableau, all with plates of chocolate cake on their laps. Dad on the left, slouching, blankly staring at his plate. Mom, on the right, staring at Ruth, worry pasted on her face. Ruth in the middle, looking out, tired and annoyed.
The balloon tied to the foot of the bed pops, like a gunshot. The tableau comes to life. Ruth picks at her cake, not eating.
Honey, if there's anything you need...
Ok. But really if you need anything sweetie, please just tell me. Ok? You are not a burden. Not at all. And I want you to feel--
Sweetie, we're out of milk. I am so sorry. I--
I'm so glad to have you home, Ruthie. Almost like you never left!
There's a long, awkward pause between Ruth and Dad. Ruth plays with her cake.
But um... Mom worked really hard on it.
Dad’s gaze returns to his plate.
...I, uh, got a new TV for my studio.
Got a beautiful picture. Four colors, eight million pixels.
I mean... well... you'll see it at some point--
Mom enters, carrying a glass of water with a cucumber slice on the rim.
Hope you don't mind I spruced up your water. Some special cucumber for your special day!
She gives Ruth the glass. A beat.
Well... I-- I've had it before. It's good.
Hey, I was just telling Ruth about my new TV.
I should've never let you buy that thing. Might as well put a toilet in the studio now. You'd never have to leave.
Jesus Christ, Lil, enough about my studio--
Mom tilts her head at Ruth as if to say, "not in front of her."
...Maybe I do watch a decent amount of TV.
It certainly does have a beautiful picture though.
Ok, you know, this whole refusing to argue with each other thing is way weirder than it would be if you two actually just argued.
Well, we don't want to ruin your big day.
Yeah, we, uh, want you to feel welcome here.
We want you to feel loved.
There’s an uncomfortable silence. Mom stands and walks around the room.
So, um, what's it like to be back? All your old things. We haven't touched your room since you left. How's it feel?
I forgot how pink it was.
I like Ripley there. Did you ever see the Zenomorph I made--?
She doesn't want to see your alien costume.
She picks up a plush white stuffed bunny from the ground. The bunny is frayed around the seams, clearly well used but also well maintained.
Yes, Mom. How'd he get over there?
God, he was your best friend-- what until high school?
You slept with him until high school.
That's just cause he was soft. I didn't--I stopped believing in him in second grade. Or third.
Ruth takes the bunny from Mom. She stares at it.
He looks a little rough around the edges.
I could patch up those spots.
When was the last time you sewed?
And didn't you throw out the machine after you screwed up one of your dresses?
Well why don't you do it? Might be a fun thing to try, you know, actually doing something for someone else.
I thought we weren't fighting today.
Ruth opens the chest at the foot of her bed to reveal a giant pile of stuffed animals. She throws the toy bunny inside and locks the chest.
Oh. Ok, great. Just, um, honey? Full disclosure: we... well, we... we took the lock off of your bathroom door.
A beat. Ruth exits into the bathroom. We hear a shower turn on.
Dad is picking at his cake. Mom elbows him.
Means pay attention for a change. Your daughter's fucking... unwell.
I don't know the right word for it.
ADD THING ABOUT WHAT HAPPENED AT COLLEGE
That's your daughter you're talking about.
Yes, Chuck. Something to get her excited. Or maybe if she had a boy... I don't know... Goddammit.
How could it be our fault? It happened at school. She's been with us her whole life and nothing ever happened. It's that school. She couldn't handle it.
I mean I just think... I... I don't know. Never mind.
"I don't know, never mind..." Is there a single word that comes out of your mouth that isn't fucking liquid milquetoast?
You're a gaping fucking cunt. How's that?
At least I have a job.
Oh, here we go. Alright. Ok, I'll tell you what, if it does turn out to be our fault, it'll be way more yours than mine. Fucking neurotic fucking harpy.
You're a worthless sack of shit.
Mom fumes and storms out. Dad collects the cake plates.
We'll be downstairs if you need us!
He exits. A beat. The bathroom door opens. Ruth peeks out, fully clothed, clearly not having gotten in the shower.
Noticing her parents' absence, she turns the shower off and steps out of the bathroom.
Ruth turns to the "Welcome Home Ruthie" banner and frowns. She gets on a chair and reaches up to grab it. Her sleeves fall down and we see large bandages on her left forearm.
Finally she gets a hold of the banner and rips it down. She crumples it into a ball and tosses it in her closet.
She sits on her bed and pulls out her phone. She dials a number but gets voicemail.

Hey, um, I don’t know if you’re getting calls wherever you are. Are you still in Europe? Um, but I wanted to tell you that I’m home now. You can delete those other voicemails. I wasn’t... they... they were... I’m home now.
It’d be good to hear from you, if you’re getting these calls. I’m just kind of stuck here. Yeah. Hope you’re doing ok. Call me.
She hangs up, upset. Some anger builds up and she hits her bedside table with her fist. BANG.
Ruth pauses, stands up, looks around. BAM BAM BAM
Ruth eyes the wooden chest at the foot of her bed. The chest is shaking. BAM BAM BAM
Ruth stands and approaches it. The sounds continue. Slowly, cautiously, Ruth crouches down and unlocks the chest. She opens the lid to reveal:
Suddenly the pile explodes outward as white fuzzy legs and arms stretch out, revealing a human-sized BUNNY-SUITED FIGURE lying in the chest. Ruth screams, then grabs her mouth.
No longer screaming, Ruth stares in disbelief. The figure's bunny suit is a life-sized version of the stuffed toy from earlier.
Bennie leaps out of the chest.
Ruth shuts her eyes. She's hyperventilating.
Do you want to play cards?
No, asshole! I'm having a fucking panic... fuck.
Ruth clutches her stomach, she's shaking.
Oh. Oh no... What do I do?
Bennie extends his arms and slowly walks forward, embracing Ruth.
Deep breaths Ruthie, c'mon. In... out... in... out...
Ruth starts breathing deeply and ever so slowly calms. Bennie, smiling broadly, stands back and takes a good look at Ruth.
Ruthie! I missed you! Man, you’re bigger than I remember.
Ruth sits at her desk, furiously typing on a laptop.
Wanna play cards? Or Hide N Seek? Ooh or Sardines--wait, can you play Sardines with two people? What are you doing?
To see if I've gone insane.
No, I'm Bennie. What's a tulpa?
"An entity created in the mind, acting independently of, and parallel to your own consciousness." Google says either you're a tulpa or I'm schizophrenic.
This is boring. None of this matters. Let's play cards.
Bennie closes the laptop. Ruth stares at him in surprise.
You shouldn't be able to do that.
Ruth stands, they walk to the bed and sit down. Bennie pulls out a deck of cards.
There's a zipper on the back.
Yeah, and I don't even want to know what'll spill out of me if that comes undone.
But if I made you from my mind--
So are these cards really there or--?
I want to know what's real.
You never used to care about that kind of stuff.
No more questions. I don't have the answers anyways. I have no idea why I'm here. I'm just rolling with it.
He deals a hand of blackjack for the two of them.
Nice! You’re so good at this!
Ruth frowns at Bennie’s exuberance. Bennie deals out another hand. Ruth flips over her cards. A jack and an ace.
What is this? Are you cheating for me?
Really? Two blackjacks, that’s just luck?
Well, you always used to win.
Yeah 'cause I was a shitty child who couldn't handle losing. But winning doesn't mean anything if I can't lose. That's the whole point.
Ok, alright. That's fine. Let's play again.
Ruth gets up, feeling the panic creep back. She starts playing on her phone to cope.
No it’s not. I keep telling you that. Who ya texting?
Tinder's an app. Dating app. Started using it at school.
Nobody. I pretty much just use it for hookups.
You're asking a lot of questions.
Go run around in circles until you get tired.
Bennie tries it. Stops fairly quickly.
I want to play a game.
Bennie you've only been here for like five minutes, and already I want to strangle you with those stupid fucking ears.
Ok, ow... But you don't know why I'm really here.
Actually I think I'm starting to get an idea. Growing up's changed you Ruthie. And I'm not sure I like the person you're growing into--
gonna try and teach me some lesson about myself.
But you don't know what the lesson is yet!

You think growing up has made me cynical or unhappy or something. You want to get me to reconnect with my inner child. To realize that cynicism only isolates me from other people and that I should be more open and loving. You're here to teach me that happiness didn't permanently go out the window once I turned eighteen, I just have to remember what it's like to be happy. That sound right?
Ok, well can we start that after dinner?
What? What is it? What whoa?
It's nothing. Just a guy from high school. Came up on Tinder.
Uh, I mean, I guess, maybe. He was in jazz band with me. Played guitar. I sat behind him.
You guys should do a duet on your date.
I am not going on a date with him.
"Uh, I mean, I guess he's cute maybe."
It's weird. He's from high school.
What if he's your true love?
Then I guess I'll die alone.
But he might be the secret to rekindling your inner child!
They wrestle for the phone. Bennie loses.
Do it or I won't stop singing that I'm Blue song.
I'M BLUE DABADEE DABADIE, DABADEE DABADIE, DABADEE DABADIE---
Bennie stops singing. Ruth remains under the pillow.
Hey, hey, Ruthie. I know you better than anyone. You
to go on a date with him. There's just some asshole part of your brain that won't let you. Do you want that asshole part to win? Or do
want to win, like you always do?
Slowly, Ruth comes out from under the pillow.
Huh, I did. Now come on.
I'll do it if you take off the suit.
Take off the suit. It's too much.
He reaches back towards the zipper. But he can't reach it.
Ah, ehh, I can't reach it.
Bennie sits down next to Ruth. As soon as she touches the zipper, he squirms.
Yeah, it was. Now take it off.
CHANGE SO THAT BENNIE IS ALREADY DIFFERENT
Bennie steps out of the suit, now wearing jeans and a t-shirt with a white Playboy Bunny logo on it.
Is this my hair? Hair is weird...
I took off my skin for you.
I don't want to look normal.
You would if you weren't like a six year old.
What's wrong with being like a six year old?
You're the one lacking empathy. Promise-breaker.
I can't believe you lied to me.
Hey, as long as you're quiet.
Ruth returns to her phone. Bennie suddenly grabs it out of her hand.
He runs to the other side of the bed.
A message! "Hey Ruth! Funny meeting you here." Oh, he's charming.
Ruth grabs the phone back. She stares at the message, a little shocked.
See Ruth, you just have to believe--
Believe in myself, right, great, yeah, lesson learned. I'm all better. You can go.
Ruth sits on her bed, considering whether to text back. Silence. Bennie watches Ruth.
She starts texting. Bennie fist pumps.
Spotlight on Ruth, staring at her phone. On the wall texts are projected.
She types and sends a text.
Haha no worries. So how've you been?
Ok, nice recovery. Now keep it going...
Ruth considers how to answer this. Then types--
Btw I'm home bc my grandads sick
Oh that sucks, I'm sorry *sad face emoji*
Are emojis inappropriate in this situation?
But it's fine, happened a while ago. Long distance is hard
So changing the subject lol, what have you been up to lately?
Just taking a few classes at the community college
But mostly I'm training to be an EMT
In a year or so hopefully!
Hey do you wanna get some coffee, catch up in person?
Silence. Ruth stares at her phone.
Can't shouldn't be in your vocab--
Bennie, I really can't leave. I don't have it in me.
Maybe you can invite him over.
No, that's insane. I haven't seen him in two years and I'm inviting him over to my house? It's weird.
Well, if he actually likes you, he'll be fine with it. If he doesn't, then he won't and you'll have figured all that out before investing anything emotionally.
Who am I and what have I done with Bennie?
Hey, this might sound weird but I cant really leave my house rn bc of my grandpa. Would you want to come over instead?
Three dots appear indicating that Nate is typing. They linger.
Time has passed. Bennie is jumping on the bed. Ruth enters from the bathroom, having put on a yellow blouse and makeup.
Stop it, you're messing up the bed.
But this is a part of your lesson!
Inner child time! Inner child time!
A beat. Ruth begrudgingly gets up and bounces with Bennie. Bennie is having way more fun than her.
Ruth stops bouncing and pulls Bennie off the bed.
Ruth straightens the bed, and seeing the Rapunzel pillow, turns it around in shame.
God this room... He'll be here soon. How do I look?
Have you been taking your iron supplements?
I'm not anemic. How's my outfit?
How should I know? I just started wearing clothes like an hour ago.
Ruth looks down at her blouse, sighs, then takes it off. Bennie eyes her bandaged arm.
Ruth runs into the closet and comes out with a sweater.
So, what are you two gonna do?
Ruth laughs at the naive question.
What? Are you gonna watch a movie? Can we watch Pirates of the Caribbean?

Dad's basement studio is dimly lit and messy with tools, scrap wood, and crumpled paper littered all around. Shelves hold various hand-painted miniatures of sci-fi monsters, as well as prop guns and other prop weapons. A wookie suit, among other costumes, is hung on a rack. A 4k TV plays the anime Cowboy Bebop. There’s a center workbench with a minifridge underneath.

Dad is at the center workbench painting a miniature model of a grey-skinned, gangly monster with no head. Its wiry arms end in clawed hands holding a round bundle. In the center of its chest is an open mouth lined with sharp teeth.
Dad doesn't notice, too absorbed in his model. Ruth eyes the minifridge right next to Dad. She approaches Dad, trying to find a way to open the fridge without getting Dad’s attention. No luck.
No, it sucks out their life force so that they grow up into soulless automatons who live only to work endlessly until they die.
Well they’re at work one day and they’re sort of compelled to go up to the roof and... uh...

Paragraph.Text: Dad freezes up. Ruth sees an in.
What do they do up there?
No, they--I mean they do something--
--but I shouldn’t have--I shouldn’t have brought it up. I’m sorry.
Dad takes the model into a back closet. Ruth fists pumps, then silently opens the fridge and grabs a bottle of wine.
Dad returns and Ruth skirts around to the other side of the table to hide the wine.
I didn’t know you were gonna be down here.
I know, Dad. It’s ok. Really.
There’s an awkward silence. Ruth can’t walk any further without revealling the wine.

Text.#text: Did you ever watch Cowboy Bebop?

Paragraph.Text: Dad turns to watch the TV, saying nothing more. After a moment, Ruth realizes she’s in the clear.
She sneaks off as Dad watches the TV.

Text.#text: Ruth enters with the wine, two plastic cups, and a corkscrew.
Finally! I've been thinking more about your lesson.

Not when we're so close to a breakthrough! I've developed a strict regimen, from dawn til dusk, designed to reinvigorate your inner child. First off, morning cartoons, then board games, then lunch, then a nap, then a snack, then Disney Channel, then a snack, then free hour, then dinner, then a movie, then a snack, then we stay up til eleven hiding under the covers just talking. Unfortunately--and I think you'll agree with me--due to time constraints, you'll have to call off your date.
Ruth grabs the wine bottle, looks around frantically for a place to hide it.
Ruth runs to her bed and stashes the bottle behind a pillow.
Mom knocks and enters. She can’t see Bennie.
Mom holds out a pill bottle.
I, um, got you some iron supplements.
Mom sits next to Ruth on the bed. Awkward silence.
I’ll give you two a minute.
Look, I understand how you feel... And I know in the past that... we haven’t always talked... about everything.
But Ruth, I... if anything... if there’s anything you want to tell me--
--Hold on. If there’s anything you want to tell me. About anything that happened to you. I just want you to know that you can tell me... anything.
W-well... um... college is--a lot of stuff happens in college. People do things. Especially when they’re drinking--
Mom, what are you asking me?
I mean, creepy assholes, sure, but that’s college, that’s parties at college. But I didn’t get--
You don’t need to say it again. I just--
You thought I was depressed because I got raped?
Stop--you keep saying--I-I’m just trying to get to the bottom of--
Of why I’m so fucked up?
No, you’re not--you’re not f-fucked up.
I’m not? Wow. I guess I can go back to school then. And those parties.
Ruth... Alright never mind. I’m sorry I brought it up. I’ll-I’ll go.
Also, I got you some milk.
Ruth, I'm sorry... I'm trying my best. I'll-I'll do better. I promise.
Oh my god, it's just milk.
But I want to help you and--and--first the chocolate cake, now this--

Paragraph.Text: I don't know what to do! I love you so much--
You can help--You can help by leaving.

Text.#text: Silence. Mom bites her tongue. She heads for the door. Then pauses.
She lobs it a bit too hard at Ruth, who catches it.
Mom exits, closing the door behind her. Bennie exits from the bathroom and gives a big expressive exhale. Then he nods his head towards the iron supplements.
A beat. Ruth opens the bottle and dry swallows a pill.
Nate sits at Ruth's desk. Ruth sits on the bed. They're drinking wine out of plastic cups. Bennie's playing with his cards, pouting.
...So now there's me, the paramedic, the driver, and the guy's buddy all trying to hold him down so we can get the IV in. But this guy is huge, like a linebacker or a fucking truck, and he does

want to cooperate--and he's still in the middle of a fucking heart attack by the way--but he's fighting all of us and shouting and rocking the ambulance so much I thought it was going tip over, all the while he's screaming about how the government and shill doctors are trying to sterilize him because he knows the truth about the Rothschilds and how Stevie Wonder isn't actually blind--
I know, crazy fucking guy. Want some more? Here.

But ok so we manage to strap down his lower half at least, and the paramedic finally gets out the IV catheter, all the while I'm fighting for my life, the guy's popped me at least a half a dozen times, but as soon as he sees the needle, just like immediately, he faints. Just like that, out like a rock. Turns out he was afraid of needles.
Oh yeah. Although he wasn't too happy when he woke up in the hospital.
I bet. Damn, that's a great story.
Ruth gives Bennie a "shut up" look. Nate, who can’t see Bennie, is a little confused.
Just that it's like my only good story. Most of the calls I've been on are for broken hips or asthma attacks.
One more good story than I have.
It's true. I never do anything fun or cool.
Believe whatever you want, man. I got nothing.
When I get back I want to hear a story.
Yes, beginning, middle, end, all that shit.
Nate closes the bathroom door. A beat.
What's your problem? Why are you pouting?
No, I just think he's got.. other motives.
Like he wants to fuck me?
That's good. I want to fuck him. We want to fuck each other.
I'm nineteen years old. I'm allowed to have sex with boys.
Nate picks up one of the stuffed animals on the ground. A pig. He sits next to Bennie on the wooden chest. Bennie scooches away from him.
They kept fighting so I staged a coup and drove him out.
Yeah they’re like... like my oldest friends. It's pathetic, I know.
No it’s not. It's like Toy Story.
Yeah, but Andy's toys were alive.
And he gave them all away in the end. I didn't like the third one.
Nate picks up the toy version of Bennie. Bennie squirms.
Nate plays with the toy version's arms a bit. Bennie's arms involuntarily mimic the movement of the toy's.
Yeah he was my first. My parents bought him at the hospital.
Ruth! Make him let me go!
Nate squeezes the toy. Bennie shivers.
He likes it when you scratch his head.
Nate scratches the top of the toy's head. Bennie tries to resist but clearly it feels good. Eventually though, he shakes himself out of it.
Ruth gets up and sits next to Nate.
Nate gives her the toy. Bennie breathes a sigh of relief.
Ruth stares at the toy. A pause.
There was one time in middle school--uh, it was way after I stopped actually playing with him. But I thought I'd lost him.
Wait, what? You lost me? Why don't I remember that?

I searched everywhere, basically destroyed my room, but he was gone. I cried for two days straight, wouldn't even eat. Pretty ridiculous looking back now, but back then it was like worst day of my life. My parents both ran around trying to be the first one to find a replacement, but of course I didn't want a replacement. I wanted him.
I didn't. One day I just woke up holding him. It was like magic. But I never lost him again.
A pause. Ruth and Bennie share a look.
Think one of your parents found him?

Don't think so. Whoever did would've told me. Wouldn't have wanted to risk the other one getting credit. Maybe I was sleepwalking and found him, I don't know. I always thought maybe he'd gone on vacation. Maui maybe, or Legoland. I don't know.
Nate holds eye contact with Ruth. Ruth gets all fluttery.
Well, the ending's sort of deus ex machina.
Yeah, but... sometimes... I kinda like deus ex machina.
Nate kisses Ruth and they start making out.
Bennie grabs Ruth by the shoulder and pulls her back.
Ruth grabs the bunny toy and pushes it away from her. Bennie is shoved back.
Nate and Ruth start up again, both getting more and more excited.
Ruth grabs the toy's head and squeezes. Bennie exclaims in pain and falls to the ground. Ruth keeps squeezing. Nate pulls at Ruth's shirt. Ruth pulls down the sleeve covering her bandaged arm.
You want to keep it on?
Ruth lets go of the toy and stands. Bennie lets out a sigh of relief.
I can come back. After dinner.
Ok. Maybe like 8:30? My fucking parents, I'm sorry.
It's alright. Hey, uh, do you smoke at all?
I can bring some if you want. Makes things better.
Ok. Again, like, really really sorry--
Nate opens the window, climbs out.
Don't worry about it. I'll see you in a bit.
Nate exits. Ruth closes the window.
She throws the toy on her bed and storms out of the room.

The dining room is by all accounts over-decorated. This is Mom’s room, and she has made it very clear. Notably we see bright flowers on a side table, oil paintings and family pictures on the wall, and a fairly elaborate light fixture above the table.
Mom, Dad, and Ruth at the dinner table. Ruth picks at her food and does not eat.
...I just, I know something happened. At school. Something. And I don't know how we can help you if you keep... keeping us at arm's length.
But you don't have to tell us anything if you don't want to.
Mom whips her head towards Dad.
What are you talking about? That's not--
Ok, yeah, of course, if you don't want to, obviously you don't have to. But, Ruth, we just, we want to know what happened. And why. We want to help, but we don't know how.
Not enough sanguine. Too much black bile. It's all out of whack.
The four humors? It's like old Shakespearean junk science.
She was making a joke, Lil.
Can I just eat? Is that allowed?
Yes, that's allowed. Of course it is.
Everyone focuses on their food. Ruth nibbles on a piece of chicken.
Bennie enters. He sits in the chair next to Ruth. He sighs. Ruth ignores him. He sighs more broadly. Still nothing from Ruth.

Paragraph.Text: You've really never heard of the four humors?
I don't know, Chuck. Maybe. Who cares?
I thought you were the big Shakespeare English nerd.
Yeah, in college. Thirty years ago.
Heyyy. Stop iiiittt. Stoooooppppppp iiiitttt heeyyyyy Ruuuuu--
Or maybe I remember important things instead of useless pop culture referen--

Text.#text: Did you just tell me to shut up?
Ok, I'm trying to help you. Do you realize that? I'm not the enemy, here. I'm not. I realize you're disturbed, but--
I don't know the right word for it, and--I understand how you feel--
--but whatever you are, however you feel, you cannot treat me this way.
No! I am sick and tired--
What? Do you want me to shut up too?
I do everything in this family.
Yes. I cook, I clean, I work. You sit on your fat ass.
It's not my fault I can't find--
your fault. There's a reason no one wants to hire you. You're useless.
Spotlight on Ruth and Bennie. Mom and Dad continue fighting wordlessly in the dark.
MAYBE OPEN FIGHT IS TOO SOON, OR UNMOTIVATED
So it's my fault you don't know how to enjoy life?
your fault that Ruth has student loans.
Correct me if I’m wrong, but when one person in a whole company is laid off, isn’t that just called being fired?
Spots on Mom and Dad out.
Fine, I'm sorry. Yeah, and about earlier too, being a grouch and all. I've really messed up the lesson.
Well of course you'd say that now. You haven't learned it yet.
You haven't even been trying. You're just sitting around acting like a child.
Well, it's harder than I thought it would be. I might have to resort to more drastic measures.
You're staying away when Nate gets back.
Does he have to come back? Can't we just watch Nickelodeon?
I haven't watched Nickelodeon in ten years.
I'm not a kid. I'm not a fucking kid! Jesus Christ!
Did you have something to add?

I don't think I've met any two people in the world who hate each other as much as you two do. It's like one day you, you both just decided the other person was fucking Satan and now you justify that by having everything the other person does piss you off. And like there are common threads to your stupid fucking arguments, like Dad being good for nothing or you being completely neurotic--both of which are true, sure. But the fights are never really about those things, no. They're never really about anything other than the unmitigated fact that you two just really fucking hate each other. And I'm sick of it.
What happened to you? What happened to my sweet little Ruthie?
You two are what happened to me. You and... everything. And I just can't handle--right now, I can't. I just want to be alone. The three of you only make things worse.
Ruth, come on! I already apologized...
We hear a door slam offstage.
What was she talking about, "the three of us?"
She said "the three of us only make things worse."
Ruth is sprawled across the bed, stomach side down. Her head turned towards the audience, she stares out unfocused, numb.
Do you want to watch TV?
No response. Ruth doesn't even blink.
Do you want to learn that inside every pessimist is a disappointed optimist?
You know, a cynic is someone who knows the price of anything and the value of nothing.
Holy crap, that worked. Um, uh, everything great was accomplished by fools who dreamed. Uh, don’t cry because it’s over, smile because it happened. Um, wait, what--what are you doing?
Ruth walks to her desk, rifles through the drawers. She takes out a pen, scrapes her finger along the tip, then, unsatisfied, she throws the pen back in the drawer.
What are you looking for? I can help.
She walks into the bathroom, rifles through more drawers, comes up with nothing.
It can be like a bonding thing. We can do a montage.
She exits the bathroom and stands around looking.

Ruth sees her Rapunzel pillow. She picks it up, considers it, and bites at one of the corners, ripping a small hole. She reaches into the hole and pulls out a long wire frame. She scrapes one end of the wire against her fingertip, testing for sharpness.
She rolls up her right sleeve. Bennie realizes what's happening.
Bennie scrambles around the bed and snatches the wire.
It's like an endorphin thing. Come on.
I'm not gonna let you-- No!
Ruth sees the Bennie doll on her bed. She grabs it.
Ruth makes the doll extend its arms. Bennie’s arms extend accordingly.
Ruth takes the wire from Bennie's outstreached hands.
Ruth gives him an impassive look and slowly scratches her right forearm with the wire. It bleeds.
She closes her eyes and exhales deeply.  After a moment, her eyes open.
Ruth stands, goes to her bathroom, finds gauze, and tapes her arm.
I wouldn't do it if it didn't.
In the distance we hear Mom and Dad start yelling at each other. Ruth groans.
They weren’t like this when you were little.
I think they were just quieter.
Ruth sits on the bed, covering her ears and putting her head down. Bennie sits next to her.
Ruth doesn't hear him. He nudges her.
The parents' yelling grows a bit louder. Ruth realizes.
Fuck. Should I tell him not to come?
Actually, I'm feeling kinda sick. Might have to cancel tonight.
Too bad. You know, if they weren't fighting, but... it's too embarassing. It's for the best.
No I didn't. I apologized for grouching earlier.
Yeah, yeah, but first you were being so annoying that I had to tell you to shut up in front of my parents, and wouldn't you know it, they got into a fight.
I said I was sorry for that too. Let's get back to the lesson.
You're not sorry, you got what you wanted. I can't have Nate over now.
That's crazy. What are you talking about? I engineered all that? Are you kidding me?
A pause. Ruth grabs her phone.
Actually, wanna meet at that park on West Oak? I'm just nervous about smoking in my house.
Druggie park? You're going to Druggie Park? I thought you couldn't bring yourself to leave.
Ruth gets up, puts on shoes.
I really need to get laid.
Ruth, you can't sneak out, you're on suicide watch.
Should've thought about that before you made it impossible for him to come here.
Ruth moves to the window. Bennie blocks her path.
Ruth tries to push him out of the way, he grabs her and struggles to push her on to the bed.
In the grapple, Bennie grabs Ruth's wounded forearm. Ruth screams.
Ruth grabs the Bennie doll and pulls at its head. The seams around its neck begin to tear. Bennie screams, grabbing at his own neck.
She twists the doll’s right arm. Bennie's right arm twists.
I'm just trying to look out for you.
Ruth stands and throws the doll on her bed. She climbs out the window and turns to Bennie.
She shuts the window and exits.
Bennie lies on the ground, frustrated and in pain.
Agh, this isn’t working... This isn’t--
Bennie sits up, holding his aching head. He looks around aimlessly, but then sees the toy bunny on the bed. He stands. He approaches the toy. He picks it up.

Bennie grabs one ear of the toy and pulls. He screams as he slowly tears the ear off. Then he rips off the other ear. He begins to tear the bunny to shreds, growing more and more frenzied and animalistic with each dismemberment. Stuffing flies all around. Lastly, he grabs the head and tears it in half, looking downright demonic.

Paragraph.Text: His demonic breathing slows, now giving way to an utter lack of affect. He stares out at us, utterly blank. Soulless.

Text.#text: Ruth is walking, calling someone. It goes to voicemail, like last time.

Hey. You’re probably not even listening to these but... things have gotten a little... weird. I can’t really talk about it without sound crazy. You know Bennie, my old stuffed bunny? Well... uh... things have gotten weird. But on the other hand I’m about to hang out with a boy from high school. He’s nice. We’re gonna smoke drugs together. Wish you were here.
Ruth sees Nate in front of her standing in front of a park bench, arguing with Kevin, a white guy wearing a du-rag.
Come on man, I know you're good for it.
Dude, get the hell out of here.
Yo, I need this. My new girl--
I don't give a shit, I can't help you.
Man that's fucking ice cold. That's freezer shit. You and me, man--
Look. Dude. I don't know you.
Oh, ok, cool man. Be that as it may.
How long has this been Druggie Park?
Think it's always been, even my mom calls it that.
My dad used to take me here to play... You know what? I kind of remember it smelling weird.
was hoping for a contact high--should I roll the j?
Nate gets joint stuff from his backpack.

Yeah, go ahead. I mean, it wouldn't suprise me if he was. I'm pretty sure he smokes. Once in high school, I found like a hastily stamped out joint on the floor of our garage. My sister was out of the house by that point so it couldn't have been hers. And there's no way my mom smokes.
She's a prude. Except with valium.
Hey, so uh, sorry again about earlier.
This sneaking around stuff isn't something I usually do--
Yeah, you don't want to get into it with your parents.
I'm kind of enjoying it honestly, the sneaking around. You know, it's like...
Nate licks the edges of the rolling paper.
Yeah. For me it's like there's a pretty fine line between excitement and panic.
Nate grabs a lighter, lights the joint. He takes a quick puff, then passes it to Ruth, who takes a couple puffs. They pass the joint back and forth as the conversation continues.
You said with the joint in the garage--
Did she go to Wilson? I never--
No. I mean, yeah she did. But before us-- she's seven years older. So you wouldn't have crossed paths.
Why the time gap between you two?
It's alright. It's whatever. God, I’m oversharing.
No, no, it's cool. I like talking about real shit.
It's nice to be with someone who feels like they're actually listening to you. My parents, they're... fuckin'... ugh.
Yeah I get that. So, how’s college?
Do you want the rest of this?
Nate takes the j. Kevin enters looking agitated.
Man, like, sorry but-but I need that shit, ok?
Kevin pulls out a knife. Ruth screams.
This girl Alexis, man--I'm a fucking toad, man, she's a dimepiece, every inch--
Get the fuck out of here.
I'm not mugging you, I just need some--
I just need something to get a foot in the door, and she's a fiend for that shit.
It's just, I could bounce a quarter off this girl's ass, you know?
What the fuck are you talking about?!

Like I'm fucking in love with this girl, man! Like really! And maybe it ain't the sign of a healthy relationship if I gotta bring candy just to get in the door, but like... shit, man, I gotta try! I don't know what else to do.
Kevin does. Nate opens up his backpack.
Nate throws a plastic bag filled with white powder at Kevin. He catches it.
You're the OG man, straight up.
Uh, I didn't mean to freak your girl out.
Sorry man. I'll pay you back. Fuck it, I'll pay you double.
Ruth is still panicking, trapped in her head.
Do you want to go home?
Nate helps Ruth stand and they exit.
Nate helps Ruth through the window, then steps inside and closes it. As Ruth wanders towards the center of the room, her breathing calms a little.
Ruth looks around, Bennie seems to be gone.
Ruth looks in the bathroom, under the bed. No Bennie.
It's really not. You don't have to say that. Uh, what are you looking for?
Nothing, uh, what were you saying?
I just can't believe him... Jesus, Kev, pulling a fucking knife... He must really love that girl.
Do you do that a lot?
Off and on. It's how I paid for EMT classes.
I-I should've told you. I understand if the whole drugs thing is a dealbreaker--
Ruth reaches into his backpack and pulls out an eightball. She tries to unwrap it. She can't.
Ruth gives him the bag, he stands and walks to the table, unwrapping the eightball.
My grandpa's not really sick. I'm home because I almost jumped off the roof of my school's environmental policy building.
Well, I had, uh, failed three midterms because when I wasn't having panic attacks I was actually extremely busy being too depressed to eat.
Ruth follows him and grabs the wine bottle from the table. She checks to see how much more is in it, then drinks several gulps straight from the bottle.
Well, are you sure you still wanna do this?
Yes. I'm feeling much better now.
Nate, you have no idea how good you've been for my mental health. Don't screw things up now.
There’s a pause. Nate isn’t sure.
Ruth mounts Nate and kisses him deeply.
Loud music blares. Ruth paces around the room talking aloud.

Like who the fuck am I supposed to blame? My parents? They're a collective fucking train wreck, and I'm positive they're why I can't handle one damn iota of confrontation--my stomach fucking somersaults at the slightest bit of conflict--but like why the fuck does my brain work this way? Is it like I'm repressing some deep horrible trauma?--like was I fucking touched as a child? I don't think so, but then if I were repressing some kind of kid touching, you know, in my past that's exactly what I'd think. I've wracked my fucking brain for some explanation, you know?--anything at all--and the only thing that makes any sense is that I was just born with a broken head, which isn't fair. Not fucking fair.
So, uh you schizophrenic or something? I mean, it's cool, but--
No, I'm like anxious and depressed.
But you can't be both anxious and depressed right? Isn't depression like you can't feel anything?

Only when it's a good day. On those days I'm just numb and kind of bored, and I can usually fix it, um... But when it's a bad day it's like I can't feel anything good, but I can really quite fucking acutely feel a sense of like, everything's just really really horrible and poisoned and tainted with this like black fog--
Do you feel, uh, like that right now?

It's still there, but the alcohol and the coke are doing a pretty good job of pasting over it--which I realize is not healthy, but when you feel like this all the time you find yourself ready to do anything--anything at all to make it stop.
Ruth abruptly kisses Nate. They make out aggressively, travelling naturally to the bed.
Ruth springs to the table and starts making two more lines.
God I haven't felt this good in... shit...
Yeah, but also like... uh... so I-I-I don't usually, um, get along or, uh, I haven't enjoyed being around another person in so damn long...
Yeah? Yeah, I mean like I really like hanging with you too. In high school, I remember--
Ah, I can't hear about high school right now, come on.
No like, I was gonna say--you remember how I'd stretch out my back a lot in Jazz Band, said it was because of my disc issues?
I just did it so I could like... look at you sometimes.
So. Wanna do these and then fuck?
Nate does a line, then kisses Ruth. Then Ruth does a line. She wipes her nose.
Only thing I don't like is the nasal drip.
Oh man, I love it. And how it tastes like all chemically.
Ruth throws Nate on the bed and mounts him. They roll around. Nate pulls at Ruth's shirt.
Uh, still want to keep the shirt--Wait--!
The shirt comes off. Nate sees the bandages on her arms.
Ruth grabs the shirt out of Nate's hands and puts it back on.
I'm sorry. I-I forgot. It’s the coke. I’m really sorry.
I wanted to keep it on. Your fucking face right now is exactly why I wanted to keep it on.
Uh, I mean, we-we can start over--
No, we fucking can't. You're not gonna be able to get past it, and I'm not gonna be able to get past you not being able to get past it. Goddammit I was so fucking close. So fucking close! Shit!
Hey, it's fine, we just probably shouldn't have done more.
Ruth, you're not ODing, it's just a nosebleed. It happens. Here, for the bleeding--
No, no I don't want to ruin your shirt--fuck I'm dripping everywhere. Fuck me! Shit!
Ruth grabs something from a pile of clothes on her floor. She puts it to her nose automatically.
Ruth realizes what she's holding up to her nose. She unfolds it to reveal Bennie's bunny suit covered in her blood. Her face goes white.
Ruth scrambles around her bed looking.
That stuffed bunny from earlier. Help me look for it.
While Nate looks in the toy chest, Ruth tears her bed apart, throwing pillows and covers, looking under the bed.
He's going to be angry, and if I don't have the doll, I can't--
Ruth opens her closet door and screams. Bennie stands inside, staring at her.
Ruth scrambles backwards and grabs Nate.
Ruth, you're having some sort of panic attack. It's ok.
Bennie steps out of the closet with an empty expression.
That's not--that's not--well maybe it is but I really don't think--
You've got to take a few breaths.

Paragraph.Text: Bennie speaks with an utterly flat affect.

Text.#text: Ruth tries to grab Bennie but he throws her to the ground.
Nate goes for Ruth and walks right into Bennie's arms. Bennie grabs Nate and throws him into a wall, head first.
Bennie grabs Nate by the hair and slams his head against the wall repeatedly. Nate is looking bloody and barely conscious.
Ruth gets up, looks around for a weapon. Comes up with the pillow wire from earlier. Points it at Bennie.
Bennie looks up to see her brandishing the wire at him.
He grabs her wrists. She screams in pain and drops the wire.
I won’t let you hurt yourself.
Sweetie, we love you! We understand how you feel!
Bennie stands, facing the door. Ruth moves to check on Nate.
Dad opens the door. Mom stands behind him.
Bennie steps up to Dad and shoves him back out the door and crashing into Mom. Bennie shuts the door, then grabs the doorknob.
Bennie breaks the doorknob off. Dad struggles with the door to no avail. Bennie pushes the toy chest in front of the door to block it.
Sweetie, we love you with all our hearts!
Nate, you have to stay awake.
Leave him alone. He doesn't belong here.
Ruth slaps Nate, which jostles him a bit, but then he passes out.
Nate is out like a light. Bennie finds his bloody suit on the ground. He picks it up and puts it on. He sighs with relief, now wearing the white fluffy suit covered in blood.
Bennie jumps on the bed mechanically, robotically. Ruth is cradling Nate. She’s on the phone again. It goes to voicemail.

Goddammit, pick up the fucking phone! You should be here—-you’re supposed to be here and-and-and shit’s really—-I don’t really know what’s happening, everything’s fucked, you were supposed to be there for me, and you--I don’t know why I’m suprised, all you ever did was leave, but--but all I know is you’re not here and you
be here. You’re my big sister, you’re supposed to be here! God! Fuck!
She tosses the phone across the room. She nudges Nate trying to wake him up.
Nate... Hey, c'mon... Please... I'm so sorry... Please...

Paragraph.Text: Ruth continues to nudge Nate until she pauses suddenly. Her head turns and she looks around the room with unfocused eyes. She speaks with a strange voice, lighter, almost childlike.
You let a stranger in here. That’s what happened.

Text.#text: Bennie gets off the bed and approaches Ruth. Ruth shakes herself out of her funk and moves to protect Nate.
What should we play? Cops and Robbers?
Ruth grabs a pillow from the ground and desperately swings at Bennie. Bennie grabs the pillow and rips it out of her hands.
Come on Ruthie. Smile. It’s fun. Laugh. You'll never be happy if you don't learn to laugh again.
No. No one leaves. You have to learn your lesson.
I don't need a fucking lesson!
YES YOU DO. When you were a kid, you were happy. Now you're not. Go back to being a kid. It's simple. Let's play a game.
You don't mean that. You're just having a bad day.
No, I fucking hate you. I wish I'd never thought of you. You've done nothing but torture me since you got here. You're a fucking demon. You might actually be a fucking demon.
I’m not a demon. I'm your best friend.
Nate! Nate, look at me. You got hit on the head. You probably have a concussion. You need to stay awake.
I'm... I'm Ruth. Ruth McCallan. From Wilson. Jazz band. Yeah?
Yeah, who is he? Dude, you're covered in blood.
Bennie grabs a lamp from the bedside table.
Ruth puts herself between Bennie and Nate.
Bennie freezes. Tense silence. Nate wipes his nose.
Aw shit, did I do coke again?
Fuck man, no wonder I feel like shit. Fucking comedown man. Always sucks.
Nate stands, gets lightheaded, stumbles. Ruth steadies him.
After a beat, Bennie points with the lamp.
Nate walks to the restroom, unconcerned about Bennie's threatening posture. Ruth keeps herself between them.
Should you be up and around right now?
Nate turns on the faucet, washes his face.
Wouldn't that've been a part of your training?
Oh. Yeah, I never made it that far. To the cranial stuff.
You never made it that far?

Yeah I only got to, like, poisonings and, uh, allergies before I left. Fucking drug test bullshit. Who gives a fuck if I get high on my own time? I have chronic pain, ok? Fucking cartilage slip disk bullshit.
No man, I'm a drug dealer. "The scum of the fucking earth." You ever seen Trainspotting?
Isn't it? Man, heroin must be wild
for it to ruin people's lives like that. Must be the best thing in the fucking world. Yeah... I should call Marcos, he's prolly got some...
You told me you were an EMT.
I did? Uh, who are you again?
Told me this elaborate story about a biker guy who was afraid of needles.
Oh yeah, that's a good one. Didn't believe it at first when he told us.
The, uh, instructor. I thought he was fucking with us, but he swears it happened.
Ruth looks at Nate with the most exhausted disappointment imaginable.
I knew he was a liar. I told you.
Whoa, nice to meet you too, buddie.
Nate tries to stick out his hand for a shake, but Ruth blocks him.
He's Bennie. He's my imaginary friend.
Bennie tries to dive at Nate. Ruth gets in the way.
I'm getting some weird vibes from you, man.
Bennie tries to attack again. Nate grabs the pillow wire. Ruth stands between them, trying to fend Bennie off.
I want him to leave you alone.
He will! You will, won't you?
You'll leave me alone if he lets you go.
Bennie, Bennie! I'll play--I'll play a game with you.
Let him go, and I'll play a game with you.
And if you lose, you stay here with me forever.
Bennie walks over to the door, moves the heavy toy box with supernatural ease. He finds the broken off doorknob and motions for Nate to leave.
Nate, you have to call the police... or--no, don't--don't call the police, call someone... I don't know, tell--tell them... I'm crazy and I'm gonna hurt myself.
Ok. I might've already asked, but what's your name?
It was nice to meet you, Ruth.
Bennie opens the door and shoves Nate out.
Ruth starts rummaging through the room.
The games are in the closet.
Ruth ignores him, continues to rummage.
What are you--? oh. Ruthie, you're not gonna find it.
Bennie grabs Ruth by the upper arm. Ruth tries to break free but can't.
Where is it? What did you do with it?
Bennie lets go of Ruth. He reaches into his pockets.
Out of his pockets comes white fluff--stuffing--and torn-up pieces of the stuffed bunny, the original toy Bennie.
It hurt a lot. But I had to do it. For us. And for you.
Ruth drops to the floor, hopeless.
In the dining room, Mom and Dad stand by the phone.
Yes, I do. They'll put her away and she'll be lost to the world. People don't get better in those places.
Well, what if we called a therapist?
Therapists have to report that kind of stuff. NO.
We don't even know what's going on. She could be--
Exactly, she could be fine. She was probably just letting off steam. And anyway we took out everything sharp.
How the hell'd you let her shove you out anyways?
I thought... she was on the other side... but that wouldn't... hmm. It's weird.
What the hell are you talking about?
Nevermind. Look, we should at least check in on her.
Mom and Dad walk to Ruth's door. They find Nate sitting against it, nodding off.
What are you doing in my house?
Who are you? What are you doing here?
You were in the room there?
You didn't see him when you--?
How could you not see him?
I just didn't. I was only in there for a second. Less.
Dad smacks him on the head.
Idiot, he's got a concussion or something.
How was I supposed to know that?
I'm not Professor fucking X, I can't read his mind.
Hey um, don't wanna be rude, but can you two please shut the fuck up for one goddamn second?
Uh, whatsher... Roof wants you to be quiet.
What were you doing in there?
Ruth? Who's this boy? Are you alright?
We're friends. From... high school? I think?
Nate gets up and stumbles downstairs and into the dining room. Mom and Dad follow.
How did your head get hurt?
I don't remember... Maybe we were roughhousing?
Maybe we should take him to the hospital.
You do it. I'm not leaving Ruth.
We have to do something. Our daughter's in crisis and for all we know she assaulted him.
For all we know she was defending herself.
Man, if she hit me I asked her to do it. I like it kind of rough.
So, uh, it was you two making all that noise?
I cannot believe she snuck a boy into the house.
Bigger fish, Lil. Look, can you get some ice? For his head.
After a beat, Mom exits to get ice. Dad sits next to Nate.
Listen, if you ever need a hook-up  for, uh...
...You know, I got you. I'll even give you a discount too, cause you're Ruth's pop.
Man it's cool. Ruth told me.
Mom re-enters with ice. Nate takes it from her.
So like, why do you guys hate each other so much?
Lights up on Bennie and Ruth sitting on the ground. The board game Mouse Trap is set up between them. The Rube Goldberg device is fully built, and the two mice are near the cheese wheel.
Bennie rolls the die, then moves his mouse just past the mouse trap space.
Ruth doesn't do anything. She looks drained, half-dead.
Ruth looks at Bennie. Again, she speaks with that strange, childlike voice.

Paragraph.Text: What are you talking about? We’re playing Mouse Trap.
Bennie puts the die in Ruth’s hand. Ruth stares at Bennie. She’s confused, she’s in another place. A pause, then--

Text.#text: That frightens Ruth back to reality. She drops the die. Bennie moves her piece past the mouse trap square and onto the cheese wheel.
Bennie rolls the dice, then moves his piece accordingly. It lands on the mouse trap square.
Do you want to do it?
Bennie turns the crank, and the metal ball winds its way through the Rube Goldberg device. Eventually the plastic cage traps Ruth's mouse.
I win. We stay here forever.
walks over to the table near the window, grabs the bottle of wine, and downs the rest of it. She sees the window. She tries to open it and fails. She throws herself against the glass.
Bennie runs over and wraps her in a bear hug, pulling her away from the window. Ruth fights it, Bennie holds tight.
Bennie throws Ruth to the ground. Ruth scrambles to the room’s door.
You made a promise. You're going to keep it.

Paragraph.Text: I can’t be here. I’m--I’m not--I can’t. I can’t!

Text: Ruth tries to pull the toy chest away from the door, but Bennie grabs her and shoves her away.

Text.#text: Ruth retreats to the other corner of the room.

Text: She curls up, hiding her face in her knees.

Paragraph.Text: It’s better this way. You’ll be happy.
I’m not--I’m not here. I’m not here. I’m not here...
Bennie crouches down. Her face still hidden, Ruth goes completely silent.
Bennie nudges Ruth. She looks up, but not at Bennie, her eyes unfocused.

Bennie snaps at Ruthie. She fliches but otherwise doesn’t seem to notice him. Her eyes dart around the floor, blinking a lot, and looking at nothing in particular. Eventually her eyes glass over completely and she goes still.
Ruth does not acknowledge Bennie’s words. Eventually though, and all at once, some life floods back into her eyes. But it’s different from before. Not Ruth as we know her.
Ruthie looks at Bennie with the eyes of a child.
Ruthie wraps her arms around Bennie. Bennie is as shocked as we are.
Bennie tries to pull back but Ruthie holds on.
No I’m not. You’re just lazy.
Bennie gets Ruthie’s arms off of him.
Ruthie nods vigorously. Bennie thinks. A beat. An idea.
Ruthie... how old are you? I forgot.

Text.#text: Mhm! I'm the oldest girl in first grade. Tina Miller's only six.

Text: Bennie is stunned, finally face to face with
Ruthie. Ruthie looks down at what she’s wearing.

Paragraph.Text: Bennie gets a hold of himself.
You... had an accident. But it’s okay. Come on.

Text.#text: Mom, Dad, and Nate sit. Nate is in the middle of them, nodding off.

Paragraph.Text: Dad jostles Nate by the shoulder, which causes Nate’s head to shake and he grimaces in pain, grabbing at his head.
Hey! What did we already talk about?

Text.#text: Now why do you keep calling your husband a worthless sack of shit?
Hey, let’s make this a salt-free zone, ok?
It's the only way to get him to do anything.

It is. If I ask nicely, the gutters don't get cleaned, windows never get washed. But when I say he should be ashamed to have a house this disgusting he actually occasionally gets off his ass. Shame is only thing that still works.
And why can't you clean the gutters if she asks...
You get trapped in that fucking studio.
Shut the fuck up about my studio.
I will when you spend any amount of time outside it at all.
I'm here right now, aren't I?
That's not true, what about your birthday?
I can't even remember the last time you did the same for me.
Nothing happened. You weren't in the mood.
It's not my fault it doesn't happen. You're the one who's never up for it.
Well it's hard to perform with her scowling at me.
When's the last time he made you...
Jesus, what the hell? Why didn’t you tell me?
Yeah, ok, go ahead feel sorry for yourself instead of for the person who hasn't come outside of a vibrator in thirty years.
Oh, so now it's too much detail?
Why can't you let me feel a little sorry for myself? Just for a minute?

You always feel sorry for yourself. That's all you ever do. You never do anything else, or think about anyone else but yourself and how pathetic you think you are. Just because you hate yourself doesn't mean you're not still the most self-centered fucking person I've ever met.
I'm not a perfect person but at least I do things for other people. At least I gave you a handjob.
Alright fine. I'm a piece of shit. I'm a fucking loser. You win.
Who cares about you? Our daughter's up there going through God knows what, and you're here worried about your fucking sexual inadequacy.
Silence. Nate's head droops slightly. Dad snaps at him.
Nate's head jerks upright. Then looks at Mom.
Pause. Mom doesn't know what to say.
There you go again, Mr. Sad Sack.

And it's worse when you're around the kids. You use that sad sack-ness or whatever to fucking offer yourself as this antidote to me. You know, me the high-strung in-your-face lawyer mom. The overbearing, half-crazed hysterical bitch.
Of course you've never said that. But that's exactly what you're implying every time you present yourself as the voice of calm. You make them think that maybe I'm not on their side, but

sure are. And it's not just that I'm the bad guy and you're the good guy, it's that you're the victim. Like no matter how badly I torture our children with my whatever--probably you'd say my 'assertiveness' but really you'd mean 'bitch'--like no matter how badly I'm a bitch to them I'm way worse to you. You're taking fire for them. You're protecting them. Fucking hero.

You see what you just did? You did what you always do. You invented a whole new reality--it's your favorite thing to do. Really. And it's a real enough reality, it makes sense, there's no plot holes, but that doesn't make it true. And don't pretend that you don't think you’re the victim too--like you're on the receiving end of some grand secret smear campaign? Sure, you do a lot around here and everywhere, but you only do it because you can't ever let anybody else do anything. You tell me to do more around here, but really, you

me holed up in my studio, too busy to screw up whatever perfect fucking glass house you've built for yourself. And if I'm a selfish piece of shit you're the fucking triceratop's dung from Jurrassic Park.
I've never seen Jurrassic Park. What's so special about triceratops dung?
It's big, it's a big pile of shit. You've never seen Jurrassic--?
Ok, so both of you are selfish assholes, sure. But why've you stayed together? I mean, twenty-eight years? Jesus fucking Christ, older than I am.
We almost divorced a few years ago, but...
--we've hit on something. Why then? What happened?
Oh yeah... she mentioned something about a sister. Ok, so she left for college--
No, she left the house. Didn't go to college, just moved out the minute she turned eighteen. Still doesn't talk to us.
Oh great, yeah, it's all my fault.
I wasn't the one who trapped her in the house for two months after you found pot in her room.
And I wasn't the one who missed her graduation to go to a fucking cosplay convention.
Ok, I'd been making that suit for an entire year--
--She told me to go. She said she didn't care.
Of course she did! People say things they don't mean sometimes, Chuck.
So, Ruth's sister left. Why didn't you get a divorce?
We always said it was because of Ruth, but... I've been married half my life... What am I supposed to do? Move into an apartment? Go on dates? Fuck.
I was never very good at being alone.
You know, my parents got divorced when I was in middle school.
Oh no, they're miserable. But they were worse when they were together. And now they're... I mean, they're both lonely sometimes, but they're a lot easier to be around.
And it's not like I'm not lonely now.
Yup... I think... even when you're with someone... I don't know... being lonely.. it's pretty much always there, right?
My head’s starting to, like, throb. I think I'm gonna... nap.
Dad grabs Nate by the arms and lifts him up.
Ok. I'm gonna-- I'll take him to St. Luke's.
Dad ushers Nate to the door. Then he pauses, turns to Mom.
They exit. Mom sits back down, looking nervous, relieved, happy, sad.
Bennie stands outside Ruth’s closet. He knocks on the door.
Bennie pulls back. After a moment, Ruth exits the closet.
She’s wearing a pink, shiny princess dress that's way too small. We can also see the bandages on her arms--she's bled through the one on the right.
Like a princess. You haven't worn that dress in so long...
What are you talking about? I wore it for Halloween at Mika's house.
Ruth and Bennie sit on the bed. Bennie sits behind her and braids her hair.
Ruth thinks. Then gives a big nod.
Mika can do a french braid. She's so cool.
Ruthie, am I your best friend?
Well... Mika's also my best friend!
You can't have two best friends.
Well, "best" means better than all the rest. You can't have two better than all the rests.
No. You can only have one.
Ruth thinks hard in that overexpressive way that children do.
But Mika invited me to her Halloween party.
Yeah but-but Mika braided my hair last week and she did a french braid. And also, um, Mika's real.
Mika only invited you because your mom asked her mom to.

I heard your mom on the phone with Mika's mom. Mika didn't want to invite you but your mom was begging her to. I didn't want to tell you, but as your best friend, I figured you should know. Mika isn't really your friend. Not like I am.

Paragraph.Text: Why doesn’t Mika like me? Why doesn’t anybody like me?

Text.#text: I like you. I’m your best friend. You don’t need any other friends. You don’t need anyone but me. And I don’t need anyone but you. All we need is each other to be happy. Ok?
Trust me. Hey. You know what we should do?
Bennie starts pretending to be a monkey. Ruthie shrieks girlishly, forgetting her sadness.
He moves towards Ruthie, arms swinging.
Safe zone! I'm in a safe zone.

Bennie keeps up the monkey business, moving around her, making noises and rattling the bed. Ruthie giggles all the while. As if they'd done it a hundred times, Bennie makes play swipes at Ruthie's legs, and she jumps over them.
Can't get me I'm in a safe zone!
Bennie, as King Kong, pretends to pout.
Ruth gets down to comfort Bennie, who then immediately grabs her.
Ruth laughs and giggles and tries to wrestle out of Bennie's grasp. Bennie accidentally grabs Ruth's wrist and she screams.
Why-why do you keep hurting me?
Bennie runs to the toy chest, grabs Snowball.
Hey. Hey, it's Snowball. Snowball doesn't want you to cry.

Paragraph.Text: She takes Snowball, but it does little to stop her sobs. Her arm begins dripping with blood. Bennie notices.
Stay here. I’ll get some bandages.
Bennie runs into the bathroom. Ruthie stands there sobbing, holding Snowball and her bleeding arm. Slowly though, the sobbing subsides. Ruth’s eyes glaze over. She drops Snowball.
As Ruthie is dissociating, we hear Bennie rifling through drawers.
Ruthie’s posture slowly shifts as she returns to her adult self. Ruth looks down at her princess dress, confused.

Bennie returns to the bathroom. Still confused, Ruth bends down to pick up Snowball. Near where he fell are the remains of the ripped up Bennie toy. Absentmindedly she gathers the fluff and severed limbs together. Then she gets an idea.
Bennie sits Ruth down and wraps the bandage around her arm. As he does, Ruth is looking around.
Um... I wanna play Hide and Seek.
Benne puts his hands in the Rock-Paper-Scissors formation.
A beat. Ruth relents. They play.
Bennie plays Rock. Ruth plays Paper. She breathes a sigh of relief.
As Bennie circles the bed, he pauses. He picks up the doorknob handle and puts it in his pocket. He enters the bathroom. He begins counting out loud.
Ruth scrambles to gather the fluff and bunny body parts together, stuffing the legs, the arms, the body. She finds there’s not enough stuffing to fill the whole bunny. She looks at Snowball.
There’s a pregnant pause, then Bennie returns to counting.
Ruth takes the stuffing out of Snowball and fills up the rest of the bunny’s body parts.
Body parts in hand, she scurries about the room for something. Eventually she comes up with the pillow wire.
Ruth looks around for a place to hide. She dives behind a dresser and starts frantically sewing the doll together with the pillow wire.
Fifty. Ready or not here I come.
Bennie emerges, stalking through the bedroom. First he checks under the bed. Then the closet. Then the toy chest.
Bennie turns and advances towards Ruth’s hiding spot.
Oh... I think I’ve got you.
Bennie creeps towards the dresser. Closer. Closer.
Then, with one hand, he grabs the corner of the dresser and pulls it away. He sees Ruth holding the bunny doll, now almost fully put back together.
Ruth looks at Bennie and shoves the toy’s head on to the wire protrouding from its now rebuilt body. The toy is whole again.
Ruth extends her arm holding the toy and Bennie himself is shoved backward, although he keeps his footing.
A shiver racks Bennie as some part of his old self comes back to him.
Ruthie--what? Why did you do that?
Bennie steps forward, Ruth rotates the doll so it goes horizontal. Bennie’s feet fly out from under him and he falls.
Ruth wraps the toy bunny’s hands around each other and Bennie’s do the same. Cautiously, she walks up to Bennie, reaches into his pocket, and pulls out the doorknob.
Ruthie, don’t--You can’t go out there.
Ruth ignores him, moving the toy chest away from the door with some effort.
Ruth is about to put the doorknob in its place when she abruptly freezes. A wave of fear washes over her. She drops the doorknob and moves backward.
Ruth drops to the floor and leans against the bed, clutching the bunny toy tightly.
You... you can’t leave. You don’t want to.
Light up on Ruth still leaning against the bed, holding the frankenstein bunny toy in a bound posture. Bennie lies nearby in the same pose, facedown.
Ruthie, please let me go. I’m--agh!
Ruth is squeezing the toy, willfully ignoring Bennie.
Please! I’m back to normal now! You fixed me!
Ruth further tortures Bennie with the doll.
Are you--are you enjoying this? What kind of person would torture their best friend--
Ruth covers Bennie’s face with her hand. Bennie’s mouth closes, although he continues to try to talk.

Ruth takes the spare end of the pillow wire and crudely sews the mouth “shut.” Bennie screams behind closed teeth. When Ruth is finished, Bennie’s screaming stops as well. He goes quiet, exhausted from the pain.

Text.#text: Lights up on Mom, standing on the other side of the door. She knocks lightly.
Ruth? Is everything ok? Your father's taken that boy to the ER.
Do you want me to come in?
Ok! Ok, I won't come in.
I'm staying right outside your door though. I want to be the first person you see when you come out.
I can't... I can't go--I have to stay... If I... outside, it-it's too much-- Fuck, I can't breath in this thing...
Ruth takes off the dress. She's down to underwear and bloody bandages. She curls her knees up to her chest.
WHY THE FUCK AM I LIKE THIS?
Ruth drops her head to her knees. She tries to control her breathing, but can't.
Fuck fuck fuck fuck fuck fuck...
Ruthie, know that I love you so much.
Doesn’t matter. It doesn’t fix anything. Just makes it worse.
Uh, yeah sweetie. And Nate’s gonna be OK. He’s in the ER with his mom.

Paragraph.Text: Everyone around me, saying they care about me, saying they want what’s best for me, fucking jamming their bullshit all the way down my throat, they don’t know how to fix me, they don’t have any fucking clue. But then they try anyway and they only ever make things worse and-and-and I’m tired. I’m tired of being alone in all this.
That gets Bennie’s attention. He tries to say something behind his closed teeth. Ruth hears, but ignores.
You’re alone? What do you mean?
Everybody leaves. Nate left. Janey left.
Yeah and that’s the problem. You three--you two have no idea how to help me or even how to just not actively make things worse. You have no idea what’s going on.

Text.#text: No, Ruthie... I understand how you feel.

Paragraph.Text: No, you don’t! You don’t! Why do you keep saying that? You don’t know how I feel! You don’t have any fucking clue!

Text.#text: You know when I came to your room before dinner?
When you came to ask if I got raped? Yeah.
Well, why do you think it occured to me to ask you that?

Paragraph.Text: Yes. When I was seventeen. And it... stayed with me. When I met your father, when I was twenty-five, I was still having night terrors and panic attacks and... and I know the same thing didn’t happen to you but, but I know what you’re going through right now, at least a little bit.
That’s supposed to make me feel better?

Text.#text: That just means I’m turning into you. I've just been turning into you this whole time. I don't want to turn into you. I hate you.
I know I don't like you.
That's ok. You don't have to.
You're unpleasant to be around. You make me anxious. Both of you.
We really screwed you up, didn’t we? But I do love you, Ruthie. I love you more than anything.
I know. You say it too much.
And we want you to be ok.

Paragraph.Text: A silence. Bennie says nothing, but he stares at Ruth, tears welling.

Text.#text: Honey, why don't you try the door again? You can do it. I know--I know you can do it.
And the sooner you open it, the sooner we'll leave you alone.
If I leave... it'll all be over, and I'll have lost... something... I don't want it to be over.
Don't want what to be over?
Not--not all this... but... something else, I don't know. I-I can't stay here anymore, but I don't wanna leave--it-it's too much--it's too much--it's too much. I just want to be done.

Paragraph.Text: After a moment, Ruth considers the wire in the bunny toy. She “un-sews” the wire from the toy’s mouth. This is excruiciatingly painful for Bennie, but his mouth is freed.
Ruth peels back one of her bandages. Bennie sees what she’s about to do.

Text: Ruth, no. Please. You’re hurting yourself. I know it feels like it helps, but-but Ruthie,

Paragraph.Text: Ruth stops short of cutting her arm with the wire. For once she seems to take Bennie’s words to heart. Her hand with the doll drops to her side, and she sinks to the ground.
Bennie struggles more, and then gives up. Silence.

Text.#text: Do you maybe want to try something for me? It's something I used to do. Might help?
Ruth doesn’t respond, but there’s consent in the silence.
Ok, so, um, if you want to you can close your eyes, but you don't have to.
Ruth does. Bennie watches her silently and with concern.
Just--well you want to start with deep breaths, ok? That's first off.
Gradually and with some effort, Ruth slows her breathing. Bennie’s eyes are locked on Ruth. He seems to feel everything she feels.

Now, um, just think about what you're feeling physically in your body right now. Uh, maybe your stomach's in knots, maybe your chest is tight. Now just live with those feelings, just for a little while. Don't push them away. Just for ten seconds, really feel what you're feeling... It's not good, it's not bad, it's just there. What do you feel?

Paragraph.Text: Dad puts his ear to the door.
I’ll stay here though, in case she wakes up.

Lights out on Mom and Dad. Ruth is lightly snoring. Her grip on the bunny toy is slowly loosening until it finally leaves her grasp. As it does, Bennie regains control of his body. He stands and towers over Ruth’s unconscious body, weighing his options, unsure for the very first time.

Eventually though, he seems to relent, and he limps over to the toy chest opposite Ruth. He sits and stares at the toy bunny, then at Ruth, curled up on the ground. Something comes over him, and his eyes tear up. Then he looks at the Mouse Trap game and Ruth’s caged game piece.

Then he makes a decision, moving to the board. He resets the board’s contraption. Then he swaps the game pieces so that his piece is on the cheese wheel. He sets off the contraption and his piece is captured.
He stands. He grabs a pillow and a throw blanket from the bed. He gingerly puts the pillow under Ruth’s head and drapes the blanket around her. He looks at her one last time.
Lights come up slowly as we see Ruth curled up on the ground asleep, lit by the morning sun. Bennie is nowhere to be seen.

Ruth’s phone starts buzzing, which stirs her awake. She groans hungoveredly, noticing the pillow under her head and the blanket around her, but then checks her phone and sees who’s calling. She answers.

Text: Janey? ... Janey! ... Hey, yeah-- Janey yes, I’m ok! I mean last night was... but-but what--where are you? Georgia? The state? ... Oh ok. No-no it’s ok. Honestly, I... I managed. ...
. Mom and Dad--No, they actually... they were fine.

Paragraph.Text: Um, it’s really good to hear from you. I missed you. No--you don’t need to apologize, you’re calling now, it’s--
Looking around, Ruth does not see Bennie.
...what? No, I’m still here... Um... Uh, can I call you back in a little bit? No, everything’s fine. I’ve gotta--
Ruth hangs up the phone and looks around--cautiously--for Bennie. She checks the bathroom, the closet, under the bed, nothing.
Lights up on the other side of the door. Mom is dozing against the door. Dad is passed out, with his head in her lap. Ruth’s calls to Bennie wake Mom up. She notices Dad on her lap.
Ruth is still calling out to Bennie.
What? Mom? You guys slept out there?
Ruth’s gaze turns to the closed toy chest by the door.
Ruth moves to the chest and is about to look inside when she pauses. She moves back, thinks. Then, she makes a decision. She locks the chest shut.
I asked how you were feeling.

Text.#text: Abruptly Ruth’s face goes green. She scurries over and pukes in a trashcan.
I drank too much wine last night!
Ruth throws up again. Then again. Then, finally finished, she wipes her mouth.

Paragraph.Text: Pause. Ruth still looks around for Bennie.
Honey, do you think... you might wanna come out now?
Pause. Ruth looks at the door.
Try what I showed you last night.

Text.#text: After a pause, Ruth stands. Warily eying the door, she finds the doorknob and picks it up. She takes a deep breath. Then
he charges forward, doorknob in hand. A rush of some dark feeling comes on, but she pauses, breathes, lives with it. She puts the doorknob back in, turns it, opens the door.
Immediately Mom charges in and embraces Ruth, almost knocking her off her feet. Ruth hugs her back, tightly. Dad stands by the door with a tired smile.
Some time later, Ruth is texting in her room, surrounded by luggage.
Hey... how are you doing? Everything's ok on my end
Now Ruth is in a new room, somewhere else. Her Alien poster hangs behind her.
Hope ur doing ok. If u want to give me a call I'd love to uh... figure things out lol
A week later, Ruth texts again.
I totally understand if you don't wanna hear from me, just figured I'd check one last time if you wanted to talk.
A pause. We see the three dots indicating that Nate is typing. Then--
Ruth, now in a green jacket, sits on a bench, checks her phone. She waits in silence. Then taps out a text.
My dad just dropped me off. I think he’s getting high in the bushes lol
(A silent beat) Ruth checks her phone again. She's looking antsy. (Another silent beat)
Kevin enters, pushing a stroller. He's dressed cleaner, still with the du-rag though.
Naw I'm sure... where?... wait... oh, fuck, shit, my bad. Yo, I'm that dude who mugged that other dude in front of you.
Yeah that was on me, straight up. Not a proud moment. But you know I got me a woman now so some good came of it, by and by.
Hell yeah man, that bitch is my world. She's changed me, man. I'm all grown up.

Look at this shit. This is her kid, little T-Rex here. Name's Rocky, after that old movie. Look at how fucking cute he is. She got me takin' him on walks 'n' shit now. Can you believe that? The boys say I'm whipped, but shit, they don't know fuck all, they ain’t never been in love.
Yo, listen. Back then, um, it looked like I freaked you the fuck out. I'm real sorry about that. Hope you're doing ok.
Alright, bet. Hey I gotta run. What's your name?
Kevin holds out a hand to give dap. Ruth reciprocates.
Alright lil Rocky, we gon’ fly now...
Kevin exits. Nate enters from the opposite side.
Your friend Kevin. And a baby.
Damn Kev. Didn't know he had it in him.
They sit. Neither knows how to begin.
How are you feeling? How's your head?
Yeah, good. Healing. Do you mind if I smoke? It's for the concussion.
Nate gets stuff out of his bag and starts to roll a joint.
Did you, uh, ever end up trying heroin?
What? Oh, did I--when I was...?
Yeah, no, and I’m not about to. Don’t worry.
So how are things holding up for you?
They're ok. Parents are separating, thank God. I'm living with my Mom in an apartment. Had to get out of that house.
Ok. How's your... how are you?
I'm ok. I mean, my brain’s still broken, but... I guess it’ll always be a little broken. And at a certain point you have to try to make peace with that.
That’s good. I was a pretty shitty substitute.
You were better than you think.
Yeah, so I just wanted to... uh, so like, obviously my memories of the night are pretty foggy.
Ok. Ok, but I'm trying to figure out... Because looking back, you were, you know, not in the best place...
Yeah, and, I think... well, I-I wasn't thinking, is the thing. I shouldn't have given you coke, and I got you pretty drunk.
Hold on. What I'm trying to say is that I... I-I feel horrible, I was a huge fucking creep, not thinking at all--

Paragraph.Text: I was just so desperate. I haven't gotten laid in so long--
Wait, what--what are you talking about?

Text.#text: I'm trying to apologize, and-and  to say I don't blame you for, you know, pushing back.
You know, you pushed me into the wall.
Of course you did. I didn't push myself.
A bunny? You mean like your stuffed animal? What do you mean?
But, what I wanted to say is it's not your fault... I was a fucking creep, I like, I-I drugged you--
No. No, you weren't... you weren't a creep. I wanted to do all that. Even though looking back, the drugs weren't a great decision. But at the time--
But I-I should've known they would make things worse--
Nate, you were one of the very few mostly ok parts of that day. Don't--don’t ruin it.
...Are you sure? Then... why'd you?... what happened?
But really I-I just wanted to apologize.
Ok, but you don't need to.
...oh shit, did I--? Fuck me. Ruth, I'm so sorry--
It’s ok. We both lied. Honestly, it doesn't matter anymore.
So, I don't know how you're feeling about us.
Would you want to try again? Square one?
But I think I need to...
I just get so sucked up in the past... I don't know, I need to...
Yeah, no yeah, I totally get you.
I, uh, should probably head out.
Ruth stands. She eyes the joint.
Ruth nabs the joint, takes a pull. Exhales deeply.
Ruth and Nate look at each other. Then, Ruth kisses Nate. The kiss lingers, neither one wanting to let go. Eventually Nate pulls back.
Maybe I shouldn't have done that.
They linger for moment in pleasant silence.
Uh, so, I'll see you around.
Nate exits. Ruth watches him go, then sits in silence, thinking. She takes a couple puffs of the joint.
They both laugh a little and kind of stupidly because they're both high. Ruth tamps out her joint.
So you, uh, got any new props, or costumes?
Yeah, actually I've got a sketch for a new model.
Dad pulls out his phone and shows her a picture. Looking at the picture, Ruth’s smile fades, her face pales.
No I--no it's good, a good... model... where-where'd
She all but throws the phone back to Dad.
Um, so it was that night.
When you shoved me out of the room after I came in, after Nate hit his head. I... well, at first I didn't think it was you who shoved me.
I thought it was... thought it looked like, kinda like, um...
The bedroom is cleaned. Some pictures are missing. The Alien poster is gone.
Ruth stands in front of the toy chest, thinking. She kicks the chest. It rattles from the impact.
Alright, I'm letting you out. But just for a second. To say goodbye.
She takes a deep breath and opens the chest. As in the beginning, the chest is filled with stuffed animals. Ruth stares at the pile of toys expectantly.
Bennie, if you're trying to scare me for the umpteenth time...

Nothing happens. Ruth leans forward, expecting trouble. Still, nothing. Ruth digs through the toy chest. Bennie isn't there. She runs over to the closet, opens it. No Bennie. She checks in the bathroom, under the bed, nothing.
Bennie, come out! Come out! Fucking ollie ollie oxen free! Where the fuck are you?
Ruth sits down on her bed, head in her hands.
I'm fucking crazy... Shit! I'm fucking crazy...
Ruth's breathing gets ragged as she begins to panic.
Ruth? You almost done? I have to get you back to your mom.
Ruth closes her eyes and slowly manages to control her breathing. Finally, her eyes open.
...I'm almost done. Just give me a minute.
Ruth picks up the stuffed animals on the ground and carefully puts them back in the chest. Then, looking inside, she freezes.
She reaches inside and pulls out something: a plush white stuffed bunny. It’s quite frayed, coming apart at the seams, but it’s whole again.

She holds the toy with both hands and stares at it, transfixed. She gingerly, almost unconsciously pushes the bits of stuffing that poke out from the bunny’s threadbare seams back inside the toy itself.
I promised your mom you’d be back--Oh. Uh, are you ok?
Ruth composes herself. Back to reality.
Well hurry up and decide, we gotta hit the road.
Do you--do you have a needle? And some thread?
